Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story:
I stare at my screen, fingers hovering over the keyboard, half-written design document blinking back at me. My team is waiting for my technical input—without it, the new feature can’t move forward, and the deadline is looming. Slack pings with reminders from the product team, and I know they’re counting on me to collaborate, to clarify the architecture so everyone can proceed. 

Just then, my phone buzzes. It’s the legislative aide I’ve been trying to reach for weeks. This is the moment—ten minutes to make the case for the bill I’ve poured my heart into, the one that could actually change lives. My activist group is counting on me to advocate, to seize this rare chance to influence policy. 

My mind races. If I take the call, I’ll leave my team hanging, maybe jeopardize the project. If I ignore it, I might miss the only shot we have at real change. My chest tightens as I weigh the expectations pressing in from both sides, feeling the impossible pull of two worlds that both need me, right now.
